abstract.t: This document summarises the Internet Engineering Task Force (IETF) - Internet Society (ISOC) relationship, following a major revision to the structure of the IETF Administrative Support Activity (IASA) in 2018. The IASA was revised under a new "IASA 2.0" structure by the IASA2 Working Group, which changed the IETF's administrative, legal, and financial structure. As a result, it also changed the relationship between the IETF and ISOC and necessitated a revision of RFC 2031.

section.title: Introduction and History
section.t: The Internet Engineering Task Force (IETF) is the body that is responsible for the development and maintenance of the Internet Standards. The IETF is primarily a volunteer organization. The driving force is dedicated, high quality engineers from all over the world. In a structure of working groups, these engineers exchange ideas and experience, and through discussion and collaboration (both by electronic and face-to-face) they strive to achieve rough consensus and implement the standards through running code.

The growth of the Internet over several decades has also led to a growth of the IETF. More people, organizations, and companies rely on Internet Standards with every new day. Non-technical issues, such as legal, administrative, and financial issues have long been an undesirable but unavoidable part of the IETF. To address these issues the IETF initially established the Poised95 Working Group in 1995 to structure and document the IETF processes in such a way as to maximize the flexibility and freedom of the engineers in the IETF so that they can work in the way the IETF has always been most successful, and to honour the IETF credo: "Rough consensus and running code".

The Poised95 Working Group concluded that the Internet Society (ISOC), which was formed in 1992, was the best organization to handle all of these legal, administrative, and financial tasks on behalf of and in close cooperation with the IETF. This led to the creation of a series of documents, such as The IETF Standards Process, The IETF organizational structure, The IETF charter, The IETF Nominating Committee (NomCom) procedures, The Appeals procedures, and so on. [EDITOR ACTION: INFORMATIVE REFERENCES NEEDED FOR EACH]

As time passed and operational experience accumulated, additional structure was necessary. As a result, documents were written in order to more fully define what was called the Internet Administrative Support Activity (IASA) in 2005. The key documents supporting the initial definition of the IASA were and .

In 2018, the IASA was revised under a new "IASA 2.0" structure by the IASA2 Working Group. This made signifincant revisions to the IETF's administrative, legal, and financial structure. One critical outcome was that the IETF formed the IETF Administration Limited Liability Company (IETF LLC), in close cooperation with ISOC.

As a result, the IASA 2.0 structure and formation of the IETF LLC have changed the relationship between the IETF and ISOC. This document summarises the current state of the IETF - ISOC relationship at a high level and replaces .

section.title: Main Division of Responsibilities Between IETF and ISOC
section.t: The IETF remains responsible for the development and quality of the Internet Standards. The Internet Society will aid the IETF by facilitating legal and organizational issues as described below. Apart from the roles described below, the IETF and ISOC acknowledge that the ISOC has no influence whatsoever on the Internet Standards process, the Internet Standards or their technical content.

All subgroups in the IETF and ISOC that have an official role in the standards process should be either:
- open to anyone (like IETF Working Groups); or - have a well documented restricted membership in which the voting members are elected or nominated through an open process. [EDITOR'S NOTE: Is "restricted" necessary here?]

The latter means that, within the IETF, the Internet Architecture Board (IAB) and the Internet Engineering Steering Group (IESG) need to be formed through a nomination process that is acceptable to the IETF community and that gives all IETF participants an equal chance to be a candidate for a position in either of these bodies.
[EDITOR'S NOTE: This next sentence is from the original RFC but not sure with new ISOC bylaws this is even the case any longer. Suggest that this be revised as needed.]
For the Internet Society, this means that the Board of Trustees should be elected by ISOC's individual membership, where all individual members have an equal vote and all individual members have an equal opportunity to stand as a candidate for a position on the Board of Trustees.

The Internet Society will, like the IETF, use public discussion, community consultation, and consensus building processes when it wants to develop new policies or procedures that may influence the role of ISOC in the Internet or the Internet Technical work.
[EDITOR'S NOTE: This next sentence is from the original RFC but not it is correct to say that ISOC will consult on technical issues via IETF I-Ds. I do not recall that on my time on the ISOC Board. Usually it was in consultation with the IESG and IAB.]
The Internet Society will always put work related to Internet standards, Internet technical issues, or Internet operations up for discussion in the IETF through the IETF Internet-drafts publication process.

section.title: ISOC's Role in the IETF Standards Process

middle.section:
[EDITOR'S NOTE: Is the 3rd bullet still correct?]
ISOC will assist the standards process by:
- appointing the IETF NomCom chair - approving IAB candidates that were put forward by the IETF NomCom - reviewing and approving the documents that describe the standards process - acting as the last resort in the appeals process

section.title: Legal Relationship with ISOC
section.t: The IETF LLC was organized as a “disregarded entity” of ISOC. This means it operates as a branch or division of ISOC for tax purposes. ISOC operates as a U.S. 501(c)(3) not-for-profit organization, and was founded to support and promote the development of the Internet as a global technical infrastructure, a resource to enrich people’s lives, and a force for good in society. Governing the relationship between the IETF LLC and ISOC is an Operating Agreement, which was agreed to in 2018. [REFERENCE NEEDED HERE?]

As a result of the creation of the IETF LLC, the IETF now has its own legal umbrella. This IETF LLC structure now covers the IETF standards and IETF standards process, all IETF officers (IAB, IESG, Nomcom and WG chairs), IETF employees and contractors, the RFC series and RFC editor, etc.

The IETF Trust, documented in , and updated in and , provides legal protection for the RFC series of documents and other aspects of the IETF. This include things such as protection for trademarks, copyrights, and intellectual property rights. As part of the IETF Trust arrangement, IETF standards documents can be freely downloaded, copied, and distributed without financial or other distribution restrictions, though all rights to change these documents lie with the IETF. The IETF Trust also provides legal protection in case of disputes over intellectual property rights and other rights.

section.title: Financial and Administrative Relationship with ISOC
section.t: The IETF LLC was organized as a “disregarded entity” of Internet Society. This means it operates as a branch or division of ISOC for tax purposes. ISOC operates as a U.S. 501(c)(3) not-for-profit organization, and was founded to support and promote the development of the Internet as a global technical infrastructure, a resource to enrich people’s lives, and a force for good in society.

Under the terms of the ISOC - IETF LLC Operating Agreement, ISOC has agreed to provide some funding support for the IETF. But the IETF LLC will be responsible for creating and managing an annual operating budget for the IETF, as well as for fundraising, maintaining a bank account, managing the IETF Endowment, and so on.

The IETF is solely responsible for its administration under the new IASA 2.0 structure and via the IETF LLC, IETF Trust, IAB, IESG, IETF working groups, and other IETF processes. A further exploration of this can be found in Section 4 of .
